lines.text: You can't shoot me! I have a very low threshold of death. My doctor says I can't have bullets enter my body at any time. I-I, eh, eh, oh, oh, what if I said I was pregnant?
Excuse me. Are you Richard Burton?
No, I'm Peter O'Toole!
Then you're the finest man that ever breathed.
Hmmm, it is little Otto. He was one of your mother's lovers. We often find him lying around.
Is he dead?
Hard to tell. He always looked like that.

[In front of 10 Downing Street]
Oh, Daddy, I do so long to meet him. All the girls do. He really turns me on!
Did that finishing school teach you to talk like that?
No, I taught them. Oh, do be a pet, Daddy.
Be a good girl, do run along and watch the changing of the guard.
I bet Mummy would have taken me in.
Mummy took everyone in.
This is your mother's room. It has not been opened since the day she left here in 1916. You see. Nothing has been touched.
It's a wild room! Hey, what an enormous bed!
The German army was very large in those days.
You better bring me up to date. Who is on what assignment?
Well, it's not a very happy picture, sir.

[Looking at a map]
Why all the black flags there?
They've been liquidated, I'm afraid, sir. Our Finland, stabbed to death in a ladies sauna bath, sir. Our Madrid, burned in a blazing bordello, sir. And, Tokyo, sir, garroted in a geisha house.
It's depressing that the words "secret agent" have become synonymous with "sex maniac."
What are you going to do?
Physically, I'm not going to do anything.
Ah, you're going to nothing me to death.
Torture of the mind. The most exquisite torture is all in the mind.
Mr Evelyn Tremble?
Yes, that's right.
Isn't Evelyn a girl's name?
No, it's mine, actually.
[speaking amorously to The Detainer, believing he has seduced her to his cause]
And afterwords we can run amok! Or if you're too tired, we can walk amok.

[taking the reins of the British Secret Service]
Oh, by the way, Moneypenny, since I've come in here, have you heard me stammer?
No, sir!
Splendid. Let me know if I do; I haven't got time for that sort of thing now.

[being led to a firing squad]
You do know of course that this means an angry letter to The Times?
Seven James Bonds at Casino Royale. They came to save the world and win a gal at Casino Royale. Six of them went to a heavenly spot. The seventh one is going to a place where it's terribly hot.

[to Evelyn Tremble entering the laboratory. He hands him a form]
If you'd be good enough to sign here, sir. It's not for me, it's for the Official Secrets Act.

[Lions approaching vehicle]
I did not come here to be devoured by symbols of monarchy.

...Handle these capsules with care. Dr. Noah's bacillus is highly contagious. This germ, when distributed in the atmosphere will make all women beautiful and destroy all men over 4'6". Please handle these capsules with care.
You know, if you weren't my dad I think I could fancy you.
That's very good of you, my dear. Rather warm in here, don't you think?
Cool it, Charlie. So you want me to go to Berlin, huh?
Now Mata, you remember the old house on the Felmannstrasse?
Yeah, where Mum had a dancing school.
That has now become International Mother's Help. But that's just a cover for its real function. It is... Does he speak English?
Hey Charlie, you speak English?
No.
Who is Le Chiffre?
Nobody knows, not even Le Chiffre.

[Legionnaire salutes and rattles off something in French]
Beg pardon?

[consults the book chained to his belt]
The French have arrived!
Look out!

[turns and punches a bad guy, then grabs his fist]
Merde!
Beg pardon?

[consults his book again]
Ooch?
[in a building that is about to explode]
What's the strategy, sir?
Get out of the bloody place before it blows up!
Come along, child. The auction is about to begin.
Auction?
Tonight we are selling one of the finest art collections in Europe.
Le Chiffre's collection?
Who?
Le Chiffre.
Who's Le Chiffre?
The man who owns the collection.
What collection?
The collection that's about to be auctioned.
Who said anything about an auction?
You did.
Who am I?
Frau Hoffner.
Never heard of her. You're insane, my child, quite insane.
I think she's right!
I remember your chap Lenin very well. First class organizer. Second class mind.
My dear, Miss Lynd.
Who are you, sir?
I am Sir James Bond.
But, I thought you were retired, Sir James?
The whole world believes that you were eaten by a shark, Miss Lynd.
That was no shark. That was my personal submarine. But enough of this polite conversation. What is the purpose of your visit?
I desperately need your help.

Grand Prix enthusiasts may be worried by the amount of time it has taken me to get into this Lotus Formula Three. What they don't realize is, although Le Chiffre thinks he has a faster car than me, I am faster in my Lotus Formula Three. Hee Hee!
I really have to note your qualifications.
six foot two and a half. 184 pounds. Trophies for karate and judo, holder of the Kama Sutra black belt.
Very impressive. How do you spell that?
I'll show you!
You're crazy. You are absolutely crazy!
People called Einstein crazy.
That's not true. No one ever called Einstein crazy.
Well, they would have if he'd carried on like this.
Mr. Mathis, there's something that's been worrying me...
Yes?
Well, you're a French police inspector, yet you speak with a Scots accent.
Aye, it worries me, too.
If I'm not back in five minutes, start without me.

[showing Bond a pen]
When the nib touches the paper it releases a stream of poisonous gas into the writer's eye.
Ideal if you want to send a...

[chiming in wearily]
... Poison pen letter, yes, all our agents say that, sir.

[Jimmy Bond is flailing his arms crazily trying to communicate]
I never should have sent him to a Progressive school.

[Giving a description of his era's spy type]
... vocationally devoted, sublimely disinterested. Hardly a description of that sexual acrobat who leaves a trail of dead beautiful women like so many blown roses behind him - that bounder to whom you gave my name and number.
Be careful, that's my loose kneecap.

[Pulls down the handle on a toilet and floor circulates to another room]
It's the first john I've ever gone around with.

[Mata just arrived at International Mother's Help]
Who are you? What do you want?
I'm here to enroll as a student.
What are you qualifications, hmmmm?
I am the daughter of Mata Hari.
Mata Hari!
You are a liar.
Am I? What about this, then?
[She takes off her coat to reveal a belly-dancing outfit]

[struggling up the stairs]
My battery needs recharging.
Maybe your head needs examining.
No, I had that examined last week.

[Vesper has just been kidnapped]
Haven't by any chance seen a young lady in a green dress, have you?

[Who witnessed the kidnapping]
Let me see, sir. Would that be a lady with a black bag over her head being manhandled by two unsavory gentlemens?
Could very well be, yes.
She went that way, sir, in a car.
[Evelyn is afraid of looking through a window]
Don't worry it's a one-way mirror.
Which way?

[He and Vesper are leaving]
Excuse me.
Willingly.
You're so like your mother, you're driving me insane.
Well, you haven't got far to go.
Come to me. Come to me, my little Mata. Come to me. Come!
[He falls off the bed, Mata opens the door]
About time you were back in your box, innit?
You must forgive me. I lose control of myself. I'm a mad fool. Mad.
You want an argument?

[In Mata's room]
Who are all these people?
They're the high priests of the temple. Okay, Fred, up it!
[a priest gets up and bows as he leaves]
What an extraordinary performance. They seem to treat you like some kind of goddess.
Well, I am the celestial virgin of the sacred altar.
Figuratively speaking, of course.
Of course.
It's vaporized lysergic acid, it's highly explosive!

[Dr. Noah declares his desire for the Detainer, who is captive, nude, and strapped down]
Do you treat ALL the girls you desire this way?

[impatiently]
Yes! Oh yes, I remove their clothing and tie them up, yes! I learned that in the Boy Scouts.
Haven't you read the papers today?
I don't normally get them quite so early.
I get them before they're printed.
Well, I suppose you can do anything if you have money.
What's the strategy sir?
Get out of the bloody place before it blows up.
Don't worry about that chair with a hole in the middle. It's merely waiting to be reupholstered.

[Eyeing Miss Lynd's ostentatious pantsuit with extravagant feathered headdress]
What a charming outfit that is. Do you often wear it in the office?
If I wore it in the street, people might stare.
Four...
[hic]
... three...
[hic]
[hic]
[during a session in which Cooper is being trained to resist women]
It goes against my nature, you know.
I sense that, too. What are you doing after the exercise?
Having my head examined.
What side do you dress on?
Away from the window.
Taxi!
Tally-ho!
The Mata Hari School of Dancing is the only truly international school of espionage in the world.
In the world.
There is no political prejudice here.
Prejudice.
We train Russian spies for America.
America.
And American spies for Russia.
Very democratic.
*Very* democratic.

[escaping the firing squad]
So long, suckers!

[Referring to a painting on the wall]
To your right Sir James Bond, Lady Mary. Daughter of Douglas McTarry, raped by the Campbells in 1622. In retaliation of which Lord Douglas sent his only son, Hamish, out to rape twel' Campbell lasses.
At-t-t the same time?

Eldest first, of course. As prescribed by scripture. Youngest bore him triplets. Their union thus bounteously blessed a contract of marriage was entered into which brought the McTarrys Black Loch, Ben Tarn, the Shagsa Rock, Glenlocke and a good stretch of salmon water.
Ah, this is where you come in Moneypenny. I want you to go through all the Auxiliary Files.
The lot, sir? It'll take all night.
Your mother did some of her best work at night.
They seem to treat you like some kind of a goddess.
Well, I am the Celestial Virgin of the Sacred Altar.
Figuratively speaking, of course.
Of course! Some tea?
Ah, cup of tea, splendid.
Its made from poppy seeds. Two cups of this and you're stoned out of your mind!
He used to say a good spy is a pure spy - inside and out.

Debussy. He plays Debussy every afternoon from sunset until its too dark to read the music. Stands on his head a lot. Eats royal jelly. Let's his intestines down and washes them by hand. Something he learned during his sojourn in Tibet.
A veritable Eden, is it not, gentlemen?
Eden without an Eve is an absurdity.
A good spy is a pure spy.
Not good, great! The greatest spy in history, gentlemen.
The true - one and only - original - James Bond.

[Making introductions]
Ransome, CIA, Sir James.
Ju-Junior Cypher Cu-Cub, in my day, weren't you, Ransome?
Yes sir. J-C-C, Class G, S-I-C 2-S-C-C-T,CIA, Washington, DC.
Calamity makes strange be-bedfellows. But, why, I wonder, in the strength of your unity, do you disturb an old-fashioned gentleman in his retirement?
We need your inspirational leadership in this dark hour.
Please give us the benefit of your inconquerable powers of deduction.
For the freedom loving peoples of the world!
For the sake of the glorious, socialist revolution.
If I may interrupt this flow of cliche, it is now that time of day I have set apart for - Debussy.
But why, why at the height of his powers did Bond decide to retire?
Mata Hari, my dear friend.
What's the connection?
The woman in his life.
I don't get it?
It was his painful duty to lure her across the Spanish frontier to France - where he stood her in front of a firing squad.
He really loved - that woman.
Good lord! Moneypenny, you haven't changed a bit.
[Long Kiss]
Actually, I'm Miss Moneypenny's daughter.
How is your dear mother?
Hadley, we're up against an opposition of fiendish ingenuity. They make incredible use of women.
Yes, they tend to, nowadays, sir.
Female spies harassed me in Scotland. Female spies chased me to London. We need an A-F-S-D.
Sir?
Anti-Female-Spy-Device. We find the one man all women want and we train him not to want women.
Naught else, remains?

Nothing to sp-speak of, I'm afraid. It was found in a tree, a hundred yards from where he stood. It took off, was it were and flew like a bi-bird. But, whether it is an article of ap-apparel or an-an anatomical fea-feature? That is the question? Should it be given Christian bu-burial? Just how pe-personal is - a - toupee?
It can only be regarded as - a heirloom.

[Kissing on a bed]
And what is your name?
Cooper, big eyes; but, don't be formal, call me Coop.
It sounds like something for keeping birds.
That's me!
From now on, all remaining agents and trainees will be known as James Bond 007, including the girls.
Won't that be rather confusing, sir?
Exactly! The enemy won't know which way to turn. You are now, James Bond.
Congratulations, 007.
And you, 007, sir.
Good hunting, 007!
Sleep on hard nails, on thinkin' on my dearie. All a long night, awake, grovelin' in grief. Comfort me, Jamie, lad. Gimme your bosom to weep on. Doodle me, Jamie.
Really, madame!
I here by claim my widow's due according to McTarry tradition, let me be comforted. Doodle me!
A quaint custom, but one more honored in the breech, than in the observance.
Then you'll have to pay the Piper!
So nice of you to come.
My pleasure.
No one can be such a perverse idiot as to assault a Customs official. It must be deliberate.
It may just be natural talent, sir.
I'm Miss Goodthighs.
I can see that. You've got your cork still in your bottle.
So I have. What are you going to do about it?
I see everything that goes on at this table. Nothing escapes me.
I'm quite sure it doesn't. But, you know, we mustn't forget, that...
[Begins speaking in an Indian accent]
the beggar who is sitting in the market place, he is completely deaf, in so much as far as listening to the song that is coming from the mockingbird, is concerned.
I'm sorry, Mr. Bond, I don't get the connection.
Aw, you will. You will.
So, that's your plan, huh? The world full of beautiful women and all men shorter than yourself.
All this trouble just to make up for your feelings of sexual inferiority? I'm beginning to think your a trifle neurotic.
This will show Sir James, once and for all, which of us has the perfect body. The poor boob!

Think of it! A world free of poverty and pestilence and war. A world where all men are created equal. Where a man, no matter how short, can score with a top broad. Where each man; regardless of race, creed, color; gets free dental work. And a chance, of subscription buying, of all the good things in life.
But, Noah, you are for all this?
No-no. I'm against all this.
Oh, I love politics!

Look at my garden. Out there - there is a b-black rose. Not dark red. But, black - as a raven's wing at midnight. Gentlemen, I would not exchange one single pe-petal of that lovely flower for anything your world has to offer, including an Aston Ma-martin complete with lethal accessories.
Proceed with SMERSH Plan B. Sir James Bond is back - with his morals, his vows, and his celibate image. We must destroy that image.
I'm Heather.
I'm Meg. Your bath is ready, Sir James.
Thank you.
At the end of the passage.
Very kind of you.
Let us help you out of your dirties.
I think, I can manage.
We always helped Daddy.
Are there any ma-man in the house?
Nane but the Pipers. M'Daddy only liked the lassies.
Your-your Daddy really was a diff-different man in Whitehall.
I'm testing the temperature of the water. As I always did for my Daddy. He used to call me his little thermometer. Well, get in!
Get in?
Get in!

[Gets in the bathtub]
You're sure I'm not crowding you?
Get in! Ah, don't you want your back scrubbed?
Thank you. What is your name, my dear?
Buttercup.
How old are you?
Seventeen.
Do you go to school?
Daddy taught us.

[Sitting in a bathtub with Sir James]
What form are you in?
You need judge that for yourself, Sir James.
What is your favorite subject?
Anatomy.

[Sitting in a bathtub with Sir James]
Its getting very cold!
Right.
My Daddy liked it hotter!
I am not your Da - quite.
Oh, my love is like a red, red rose - that's newly sprung in June.
My dear.
One more request, the last. Think of me as the second woman in your life - the one after Mata Hari. Kiss me, Jamie. Kiss me, goodbye.
I must say, this place brings back a few memories.
Yes. Mother told me some of them.

[Opens liquor cabinet]
She probably also told you that I'm partial to jasmine tea.

[Writes it down]
Jasmine tea, sir.
Eh, wIll you be needing me tonight, sir?
Very probably.

[Kisses Cooper]
Doesn't that do something to you, 007?
It does. But, I'm being trained to ignore it. Beauty's only skin deep.
How 'bout some skin diving?
Do you know me from somewhere?
Your book, "Tremble and Buckle". I've studied it very closely - at night - in my bed.
Is that where you study it?
Why don't you come down to me?
Thank you very much. Lovely place you've got down there.
I do so like to feel comfortable with whatever I'm doing.
Oh, yes, in deed. Yes. The more relaxed the muscles, the - better the synchronization between mind and body.
I should think you're frightfully synchronized, Mr. Tremble. Martini?
What about them?
I was about to offer you one.
There are things I didn't understand to well in your book. Let me see, eh, was it in Chapter 7 or Chapter 6?
Chapter 6, probably. Then, of course, it could have been, Chapter 7. Have you got the book or is it still in your bed?
I believe it is.
Oh! You want me to be a spy - like mum, huh? Well.
Family tradition, my dear.
Do I get an exploding brief case and a secret transmitter?
That won't be necessary.
Well, I have to have some equipment.
Your mother wiped out three divisions of infantry and five brigades of calvary and, well, frankly, she had much less equipment than you have.
You must forgive me, I lose control of myself. I'm a mad fool. Mad.
You want an argument?
Remember, forget everything I tell you.
My lips are sealed.
Lips! Those lips that...
Run. Run along, son.
Gentlemen, I'm here tonight on behalf of my client, Le Chiffre - of whom you all have heard - to offer by auction this unique collection of art treasures. Are there any specific bidding instructions?
Our instructions are that when we are sitting we are bidding. When we are stranding we are not bidding.
We'll do our bidding sitting down. When we're standing up, we're not bidding.
We stand, we bid. We no stand, we no bid.
And, eh, the British representatives?
Well, I-I don't know, actually. Sort of, a bit of both, I suppose, really. Is that alright with you chaps?
Tell me, Miss Goodthighs, how much did you tip the porter to let you in here?
I just showed him a little kindness.
How much?
Not too much. He's 83.
Oh, it's a good year.
So, what can I do for you?
The question should be what can I do for you?
Good. You got any suggestions?
Yes. For one.
[Draws him close for a kiss]
Tell me about yourself, James.
Oh, well, I've had some pretty wild times in my life. Em, could you move over a bit. You're lying on my loose change.
Mmm, James, I *need* you.
Yes, yes, yes. Well, I can understand that, my dear. I can understand that.
I want to know you better.
You're absolutely right.

[to Miss Goodthighs]
Look, I think I better - freshen up a bit. Quick. I'll be back in five minutes. If I'm not, start without me.
Thank you, Monsieur. Could we have the name please?
Bond. James Bond.
James Bon - James Bond?
Yes. James Bond.
Yes. James Bond.
I wonder if you'd be kind enough to sign my autograph book. It's not for me, you understand, it's, eh, my little sister.
Bond? James Bond? The name is familiar.
I don't believe I've had the pleasure. Though, I'm flattered you've heard of me.
I have heard of you; but, not as an expert on baccarat.
It looks as though luck isn't on your side of the road tonight, old man.
She has a habit of moving around.
Never trust a rich spy!
I went through a lot of trouble to bring you here.
Dear Vesper, the things you do for money.
This time it's for love, Sir James.
